de.tif.jacob.core.data
Interface IDataTransaction

All Known Subinterfaces:
IDataMultiUpdateTransaction
public interface IDataTransaction

A data transaction provides the ability to flush (commit) multiple record modifications at once by means of calling commit(). With a single transaction record modifications in multiple data sources could be performed.

Note that the actual implementation does not support 2-phase commit functionality so far. This means that there is no guarantee for atomic modifications across multiple data sources, i.e. if commit fails not all modifications might be rolled back completely. Nevertheless, this functionality is guaranteed for modifications on a single data source which supports transaction handling as most relational databases do.

There is no (explicit) rollback method nor functionality, since modifications are not written to a data source until commit() is called. Nevertheless, a rollback is executed implicitly on data source transactions obtained during commit, in case any underlying data source operation fails.

Data transaction can not be reused, i.e. data transactions are invalid after commit() or close() has been invoked.

close() should be called explicitly on data transactions obtained by IDataAccessor.newTransaction() to ensure that transaction resources (i.e. record locks) are released properly in error case. Please, look at the following example how to do this correctly: 

 IDataTransaction transaction = accessor.newTransaction();
 try
 {
   IDataTable requestTable = accessor.getTable("request");
   IDataTableRecord requestRecord = requestTable.newRecord(transaction);
 
   requestRecord.setValue(transaction, "createtime", "now");
   // do further modifications..
 
   // try to commit
   transaction.commit();
 }
 finally
 {
   // in case of an exception close() will be called as well   
   transaction.close();
 }

A data transaction instance could be obtained by means of

  • IDataAccessor.newTransaction(),
  • IDataTableRecord.getCurrentTransaction(),
  • IDataTable.getTableTransaction(),
  • IDataTable.startNewTransaction(),
  • newEmbeddedTransaction(de.tif.jacob.core.data.IDataTransaction.EmbeddedTransactionMode).

    Method Detail

    lock

    void lock(IDataRecord record)
          throws RecordLockedException
    Locks the given record within the context of this transaction. The lock will be implicitly released again, if the transaction is either committed or closed.

    Parameters:
    record - the record to lock
    Throws:
    RecordLockedException - if the record is already locked within the context of another transaction.

    omitLocking

    void omitLocking(IDataRecord record)
    Prevents that the given record will be locked within the context of this transaction. This is useful to update a record in the case, that another transaction has already (pessimistically) locked the record.

    Explanation: Subsequent calls of setter methods such like IDataTableRecord.setValue(IDataTransaction, String, Object) will never fail because the record is already locked.

    Parameters:
    record - the record to omit locking
    Since:
    2.7.4

    commit

    void commit()
            throws UserException,
                   java.lang.Exception
    Flushes all modifications to the underlying data sources and commits them as well.

    Throws:
    UserException - This kind of exception (normally) indicates that the commit operation is aborted due to a failed consistency check. Consistency checks could be performed in table hooks as well and should always lead to a UserException, if the data to be committed is not consistent in a certain way. See also DataTableRecordEventHandler.beforeCommitAction(IDataTableRecord, IDataTransaction).
    java.lang.Exception - in case of any other error

    close

    void close()
    Closes the transaction which ensures that all transaction resources are released properly.

    getId

    long getId()
    Returns the unique transaction id.

    Note: This id is unique for the respective jACOB application server instance, but not unique across a jACOB application server cluster!

    Returns:
    the transaction id.

    isValid

    boolean isValid()
    Checks whether this transaction is valid.

    Returns:
    true if the transaction is valid, otherwise false

    getUser

    IUser getUser()
    Returns the user who has initiated this transaction.

    Returns:
    the transaction user

    java.util.Locale getApplicationLocale()
    Returns the locale of the current application.

    Returns:
    Locale of the current application
    Since:
    2.7.2
    See Also:
    Context.getApplicationLocale()

    getTimestamp

    java.sql.Timestamp getTimestamp()
    Returns the transaction timestamp.

    Note: The timestamp is created upon the first request of this method, i.e. subsequent requests will return the same timestamp.

    Returns:
    The transaction timestamp
    Since:
    2.7.2

    setProperty

    void setProperty(java.lang.Object key,
                 java.lang.Object value)
    Sets a property for transaction life time.

    Parameters:
    key - the property key
    value - the property value or null to reset the property
    Since:
    2.7.2
    See Also:
    getProperty(Object)

    getProperty

    java.lang.Object getProperty(java.lang.Object key)
    Gets a property value.

    In contrast to setProperty(Object, Object) this method can be called after a transaction has been committed or closed.

    Note: If a property value has been set by means setProperty(Object, Object), this value will be returned. Otherwise, if a property value exits for the current context (see Context.getProperty(Object)), this value will be returned in a subordinated manner.

    Parameters:
    key - the property key
    Returns:
    the requested property value or null
    Since:
    2.7.2
    See Also:
    setProperty(Object, Object)

    setHintForNewRecordNumber

    void setHintForNewRecordNumber(ITableAlias alias,
                               int newRecordNumber)
    Gives the transaction a hint of how many new records of a given table alias will be created in the following by means of this transaction.

    This method can improve the performance then inserting multiple records of the same table alias within a single transaction.

    Important note: newRecordNumber should be set as accurate as possible to avoid "gaps" for record pkeys. For example: If newRecordNumber is simply set to 100 and just 3 records are created, the pkeys could be 1023, 1024, 1025, GAP, 1123.

    Parameters:
    alias - the table alias for which records are created in the following
    newRecordNumber - the number of records of the given table alias
    Since:
    2.8.1

    setHintForNewRecordNumber

    void setHintForNewRecordNumber(java.lang.String alias,
                               int newRecordNumber)
    Gives the transaction a hint of how many new records of a given table alias will be created in the following by means of this transaction.

    This method can improve the performance then inserting multiple records of the same table alias within a single transaction.

    Important note: newRecordNumber should be set as accurate as possible to avoid "gaps" for record pkeys. For example: If newRecordNumber is simply set to 100 and just 3 records are created, the pkeys could be 1023, 1024, 1025, GAP, 1123.

    Parameters:
    alias - the name of the table alias for which records are created in the following
    newRecordNumber - the number of records of the given table alias
    Since:
    2.8.1

    newEmbeddedTransaction

    IDataTransaction newEmbeddedTransaction(IDataTransaction.EmbeddedTransactionMode mode)
    Creates a new embedded transaction of this transaction (parent transaction). Embedded transactions will be committed and closed implicitly when commit() or close() is called on the parent transaction. Nevertheless, committing or closing an embedded transaction, will either commit or close its parent transaction and also underlying embedded transactions of the embedded transaction (if existing) and so forth.

    Parameters:
    mode - the embedded transaction mode
    Returns:
    the embedded transaction
    Since:
    2.8
